title: First letters: அ, ஆ, ம, ப, ட
pages: Welcome! Let's learn Tamil!

There are 247 letters in the Tamil alphabet, and while this may seem daunting at first, it follows a pattern that gets easier to follow as we go along.

There are only 30 basic letters - 12 vowels and 18 consonants.

Rest of the alphabet is derived from these 30 basic letters with few patterns.

Hence Tamil is one of the easier languages to learn.
In the first lesson, we will learn 2 vowels and 3 consonants.
The first vowel of the tamil alphabet is அ, pronounced like the A in 'allow'.
Whenever I introduce a new vowel, remember to pronounce it out of your mouth so you get used to it. It's really important to practice these sounds if you want to learn efficiently!
Also, whenever there is a GIF as shown, practice drawing it by writing it or even just tracing it with your finger.
The second vowel is simply the long version of அ, which is written as ஆ. Simply pronounce it twice as long as அ!
The first consanant we will learn is ம், pronounced like the English letter M.

Next we will see how consonants are combined with vowels.
With the vowels we have learned so far - அ (a) & ஆ (aa) , there are three ways this consonant shows up:
ம் (m), ம (ma), and மா (maa)
ம்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ம: When it is written without a dot, it defaults to the அ vowel, resulting in the 'ma' sound.
ம் + அ = ம

மா: When "ா" is present after a consonant, it is the ஆ vowel, resulting in the 'maa' sound.
ம் + ஆ = மா
The next consonant is the ப், pronounced like the English letter P.
Now let's look at combining ப் with vowels. The same rules that apply to ம் (m), ம (ma), மா (maa), also apply to ப் (p), ப (pa), பா (paa).
ப்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.
ப் combined with அ makes ப (pa). ப் + அ = ப
ப் combined with ஆ makes பா (paa). ப் + ஆ = பா
The next consonant we learn is the ட், pronounced like the English letter T.
Now let's look at combining ட் with vowels. The same pattern we saw with ம் (m), ம (ma), மா (maa) and ப் (p), ப (pa), பா (paa) continue here.
ட்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.
ட் combined with அ makes ட (ta). ட் + அ = ட
ட் combined with ஆ makes டா (taa). ட் + ஆ = டா

Note: In Tamil, hard consonants like ப and ட will be pronounced differently based on where they appear in the word.
For example, ப can represent the sound of pa or ba. ட can represent the sound of ta or da.
You will learn this better as you get familiar with more words
Now, let's put what you've learned to practice!

title: Adding 3 consonants: க, த, ச
pages: Introducing three letters this lesson just to keep it simple and expand on the usage of the அ and ஆ vowels.
க்: pronounced somewhere between English K and G. Depending upon the context, it can represent K, G or H sounds.
க் combined with அ makes க (ka). க் + அ = க
க் combined with ஆ makes கா (kaa). க் + ஆ = கா
த்: pronounced like 'th' in English. It's the 'th' used in Tamil! Depending upon the context, it can represent th or dh sounds.
த் combined with அ makes த (tha). த் + அ = த
த் combined with ஆ makes தா (thaa). த் + ஆ = தா
ச்: pronounced like 'ch' in English. Depending upon the context, it can represent ch or s sounds.
ச் combined with அ makes ச (cha). ச் + அ = ச
ச் combined with ஆ makes சா (chaa). ச் + ஆ = சா
Now let's review what you learned!

title: Knee! இ, ன, ண, ந
pages: This level might be a little tricky for new learners who have no experience whatsoever. I'll try and take it slow!
Let's get into the consonants first: ன, ண, ந. They all sound like the same english letter: N.

Why on earth would Tamilians make three different letters for the same sound? Well, as we continue learning the language, it's just one of those rules that become more common and that we have to deal with.
So, lets compare the two that look similar, ன and ண. These two actually have a slightly different pronounciation that can be hard to miss!

Notice where your tongue goes when you pronounce 'n'. The difference between the two looped (ன) and three looped (ண) is where you place your tongue. For the two looped you place it next to your teeth, and the three looped is placed farther back on the roof of your mouth.

Tongue placement is important when pronouncing certain consonants in Tamil. I will expand on this in later lessons, but it's important to know that there are two different types of 'n'. I will admit, however, when you hear it there seems to be no difference, and are easy to mix up!
The last 'n', ந, is pronounced like the two looped 'n' (ன) but is only used in the beginning of words and right before த. ன and ண NEVER come in the beginning of a word!
Pay attention to correct pronunciation, and notice where the different Ns are while learning these new words!
Now, let's introduce the new vowel: இ, pronounced like the i in 'bin'. Practice drawing this vowel, it might be a little tricky at first!
To combine இ with consonants, you add an arc from on top to the bottom right of a consonant. பி (pi), மி (mi), தி (thi), கி(ki) , டி(di)

title: Ear! ஈ, ர, ற
pages: New vowel: ஈ, the longer version of இ.
To combine it with consonants, you add a loop at the top at the same place where இ's line was.
The next two consanants are both a version of R. Same as the last lesson, these two vary in their pronounciation depending on where you place your tongue.

ர is the 'softer version', ற is the 'harder version', which just means you place your tongue farther in. (when ர் is written, the bottom line is often ommited as it's not really needed. it's still a good practice to write it though)
It's important that ற has another way to being pronounced, when it's placed like so: ற்ற. This makes the ற் be pronounced like a t, so it makes a 'tr' sound.
While this next set of words doesn't have a double ற, there will be some in the future, so watch out for those!
With the introduction of ர and ற, we can also expand on the ன, ண, and ந rules from before.
ன is called றன்னகரம் as it is used when paired with ற (as ன்ற).
ண is called டண்ணகரம் for the same reason (as ண்ட)
And remember, only ந goes in the beginning of the words, and is called தந்நகரம் because it shows up in the middle of words as ந்த.
I'll remind you that as you recognize more and more words, the pattern becomes more evident and easier to tell which one to use when hearing a new word.

title: Aisle! ஐ, ள, ல, ழ
pages: New vowel: ஐ, pronounced ai.

To combine ஐ with consonants, you add
ை
character before the consonant.
For example பை (pai), மை (mai), டை (tai), கை (kai), தை (thai), நை (nai), ணை(nai), னை(nai), ரை(rai), றை(rai)

The new consonants we are going to learn in this lesson represent L sound.
But as with N sound (ன, ண, ந) and R sound (ர, ற), L sound has three variations in Tamil. ல, ள, ழ

It is important to learn the right pronunciation of these different sounds. If you use the wrong version, meaning of the words could be different. Hence it is important to pronounce it correctly so that you can write it correctly.
Pronouncing it the right way is easy once you understand where you have to place your tongue for each consonant. Practice putting your tongue in the different places.

ல is pronounced at the front. ள is pronounced in the middle. ழ is pronounced by flipping the tongue all the way to the back. See the picture. ழ is special to Tamil. So sometimes zha is used as a romanized version.

Now let's see how these new consonants we learned here will appear with ஐ.
லை, ளை, ழை

title: YaaY! எ, ஏ, ய, வ
pages:
In this lesson we will learn two new vowels and two new consonants.
Let's first look at the vowels
எ pronounced like E in 'let'
ஏ (pronounced like ae) is longer version of எ.

To combine எ with consonants, you add
ெ
character before the consonant.
For example பெ (pe), மெ (me), டெ (te), கெ (ke), தெ (the), நெ (ne), ணெ (ne), னெ (ne), ரெ (re), றெ (re), லெ (le), ளெ (le), ழெ (le)

To combine ஏ with consonants, you add
ே
character before the consonant.
For example பே (pae), மே (mae), டே (tae), கே (kae), தே (thae), நே (nae), ணே (nae), னே (nae), ரே (rae), றே (rae), லே (lae), ளே (lae), ழே (lae)
The new consonants we are going to learn in this lesson are ய்  (represent the consonant form of y and pronounced iy) and வ் (represent v sound).

Now let's see how these new consonants ய் and வ் will appear with எ and ஏ.
ய் with எ is யெ (ye)
ய் with ஏ is யே (yae)
வ் with எ is வெ (ve)
வ் with ஏ is வே (vae)
Now you can see how all these letters follow the pattern and how easy it is to learn Tamil. Let's review what we learned in this lesson!
